snippet: Chinese officials will allow Chen Guangcheng to travel to the United States with his family, American officials said, but Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton cautioned that this case still unresolved.
abstract: China and the United States reach a deal that calls for dissident Chen Guangcheng to travel to the United States with his family; compromise ends an eight-day diplomatic crisis that had threatened to strain the relationship between the two countries, but it is unlikely to silence accusations that the Obama administration bungled the case by handing Chen over to the Chinese without assurances that he would be safe.

byline.original: By JANE PERLEZ and MICHAEL WINES
byline.contributor: Sharon LaFraniere contributed reporting. Research was contributed by Edy Yin, Mia Li, Li Bibo and Bree Feng.

lead_paragraph: Chinese officials will allow Chen Guangcheng to travel to the United States with his family, American officials said, but Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton cautioned that this case still unresolved.

headline.seo: China Opens Way for Dissident to Come to U.S.
headline.main: Nascent Deal Would Let Dissident From China Study in U.S.
headline.print_headline: Deal Would Let China Dissident And Family In U.S.

keywords.value: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
keywords.name: subject
